body:
Hi Pedigo, I have implemented the parallelized FAQ function. But the run time is not shorten so far. Here is a simple comparison between Ali's code and my code (with parallel function). 
https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/SHAAAAN/MyGraspy/blob/master/withPar.ipynb

From the results, I'm not sure whether my understanding of this issue is correct. My code is here: https://github.com/SHAAAAN/MyGraspy/blob/master/codes/par304.py  Please let me know if there is something wrong with my code or understanding.

Hi Shan, without looking at the code more closely, first thing you should
definitely try is making the problem bigger. That is, run it on larger
graphs or with more inits. This may help see more of a difference. Also
don't need to compare to barycenter

On Thu, Mar 5, 2020, 5:31 AM ShanQiu <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Hi Pedigo, I have implemented the parallelized FAQ function. But the run
> time is not shorten so far. Here is a simple comparison between Ali's code
> and my code (with parallel function).
>
> https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/SHAAAAN/MyGraspy/blob/master/withPar.ipynb
>
> From the results, I'm not sure whether my understanding of this issue is
> correct. My code is here:
> https://github.com/SHAAAAN/MyGraspy/blob/master/codes/par304.py Please
> let me know if there is something wrong with my code or understanding.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/neurodata/graspy/issues/300?email_source=notifications&email_token=AGEF4HZHVZQHOI4T7JYQNXTRF42JHA5CNFSM4J36N2K2YY3PNVWWK3TUL52HS4DFVREXG43VMVBW63LNMVXHJKTDN5WW2ZLOORPWSZGOEN3YTSQ#issuecomment-595036618>,
> or unsubscribe

> .
>

Also while the above could still be a good idea. Each run of "forloop"
should only compute one run of FAQ. There should not be a for loop inside
of it. You should call "forloop" n_init times. Make sense?

On Thu, Mar 5, 2020, 8:01 AM Benjamin Pedigo <benjamindpedigo@gmail.com>
wrote:

> Hi Shan, without looking at the code more closely, first thing you should
> definitely try is making the problem bigger. That is, run it on larger

>
>> Hi Pedigo, I have implemented the parallelized FAQ function. But the run
>> time is not shorten so far. Here is a simple comparison between Ali's code
>> and my code (with parallel function).
>>

>> or unsubscribe
>> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AGEF4H7O5IPEJTVZSOQMGKTRF42JHANCNFSM4J36N2KQ>
>> .
>>
>

> Each run of "forloop" should only compute one run of FAQ. There should not be a for loop inside of it.

Hi Pedigo, I'm not clear about this comment. So far, the process is that the forloop function returns a score_new and a perm_inds_new(the permutation order) for each run and I save them in result matrix. After running self.n_init times, the result matrix will have self.n_init rows. Then select the smallest score from the result matrix and its corresponding perm_inds_new and replace the previous one. Can you tell me whether it make sense or not? If not, what is the problem of it?
And with 500 vertices, n_init=80, the runtime is 566.39 vs 345.27, which means it is faster with parellel function. And if we fix the n_jobs=5, the run time is 328.86, which is shorter than n_jobs=self.n_init. I think we also need to consider the trade-off.

Here is the updated notebook: https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/SHAAAAN/MyGraspy/blob/master/codes/withPar.ipynb

NVM you are right, the name init_num made me think n_init

What about the other thing I suggested?

Hi Pedigo, I'm not clear about this comment. So far, the process is that the forloop function returns a score_new and a perm_inds_new(the permutation order) for each run and I save them in result matrix. After running self.n_init times, the result matrix will have self.n_init rows. Then select the smallest score from the result matrix and its corresponding perm_inds_new and replace the previous one. Can you tell me whether it make sense or not? If not, what is the problem of it? — You are receiving this because you authored the thread. I've tried 500*500 graphs with 50 inits and the results are as above. Not sure what else I haven't implemented yet?

Can you show me? How about run 200 inits?

Hi Pedigo, this time I used google Colab with GPU accelerator. Running 200 inits took too much time that the Colab website would break while running. So I still ran 80 inits with 500 vertices for both functions. It seemed like slower with parallel function unfortunately. Jovo asked me to write it in Scipy style, but I am not sure we need parallelize FAQ or SGM now.

Here is the output of the experiments:
https://github.com/SHAAAAN/MyGraspy/blob/master/parellel/withPar309.ipynb

issue.title: parallel graph match
issue.body:
Closes #300 

<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the contribution guidelines: https://github.com/neurodata/graspy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-checklist
-->


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

This PR includes parallelized graph match algorithm.

#### Any other comments?

The outputs of comparison between not parallelized and parallelized algorithms for running time and match ratio are as follows. 

Parameters:
vertices: 99*99
initial times: 30
gmp: True
init_method: "rand"
seed number: [3, 8]
runs: 30 graphs / seed number

![Screen Shot 2020-05-02 at 4 47 11 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45969738/80891839-a6d13b80-8c94-11ea-9fbe-ae273eb090d0.png)

![Screen Shot 2020-05-02 at 4 47 17 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45969738/80891840-a9cc2c00-8c94-11ea-81eb-19b86824f46c.png)



#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.
Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

Reference
[1] J.T. Vogelstein, J.M. Conroy, V. Lyzinski, L.J. Podrazik, S.G. Kratzer,
        E.T. Harley, D.E. Fishkind, R.J. Vogelstein, and C.E. Priebe, “Fast
        approximate quadratic programming for graph matching,” PLOS one, vol. 10,
        no. 4, p. e0121002, 2015.
[2] D. Fishkind, S. Adali, H. Patsolic, L. Meng, D. Singh, V. Lyzinski, C. Priebe,
        Seeded graph matching, Pattern Recognit. 87 (2019) 203–215
